Eight undergraduates have just
been honored by election into the
Alpha Chapter of Maryland of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society. They
are Rubin Flocks, Alger Hiss, A.
Strathman, Albert E. Blumberg.
Joel I. Seidman, Morris Rosenfeld, Louis B. Zi v, and Leon Lachman.
Graduate students in philosophy

BARNSTORMERS ELECT
RODGERS PRESIDENT
I. Evans Rodgers wag elected president of the Barnstormers Club at the annual
banquet of that organization,
held Friday. night. Walter
Broening was voted secretary. Charles Hines is business manager for next year
and Hadley King, production
manager.
About forty members,
alumni and guests attended,
including Charles Evans, star
of the Purple _Mask and
George less, who played in
the production of 1924 and
•1995.
•Pop" Swindell was presented with a silver tray,
cocktail shaker and ,eight
glasses by members of the
cast of His Majesty Bunker
Bean, in recognition of his
services as coach of this
year's production.

The Johns Hopkins quartet of quarter milers finished
third in the mile relay at
the Penn Relays last week.
George Hemmeter, anchor
man, made.up five yards on
the last lap and finished. but
inches behind the two leaders, Rutgers and New York
University. The last thrilling lap broUght the crowd to

place, but showed great im.provement over his last year's
form. Hopkins' chances in
other events were hurt by injuries which prevented Captain Heyn and Meredith
fyom competing at the carnival.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1926.

A NEW PRECEDENT
Has a new precedent been set as a result- of the Barnstormers' election of officers for next year? After the question
of whether a man should hold office on the campus when he
is not a regularly enrolled student in one of the undergraduate
departments has been discussed pro and con for several months,
the Barnstormers, at least, seem'to have arri-ved 'at- a definite
conclusion, as their choice for Business Manager indicates.
•
The reasons for their decision seem logical and fair. They
have picked a man who has done good work, who seems perfectly
capable of filling the position.to ,which he has been elected, and
who is practically certain of returning to the University next
year. If the matter concerned the Club alone, we,.would have
no criticism to offer.'
But the -Barnstormers are an integral part of the whole
system of- undergraduate activities which are under the control
of the Student Activities Council, and all their actions should
be viewed in the light of -this fact. No matter what the conditions may be,- the election to office of a man not in college is
in direct opposition to the system upon which Hopkins activities
are based. Each organization receives a share of the compulsory
activities fee, and it is only fair that •offices in the activities
should be open only to the reg-glarly accredited students who
help support them. Added to this .is the more important fact
that since -the activities are operated under the control of the
University; as purely secondary to regular collegiate work, they
are open only to members of -the University, with the added provision that they stand well in their studies.
The present situation seems, then, a bit,incongruous, especially in view of the fact that there were men eligible for the office
who are taking a requisite number of ourses and who have succeeded in keeping off the black list. The NEWS-LETTER would
suggest-that the matter be taken up by either the Dean or the
Student Council, so that by altering the rules to fit the case,
or by adjusting the case to fit the rules, the matter may be
settled once for all.

HOPKINS LEADS AGAIN
The latest exemplification of the "spirit of Hopkins idealism"'so strongly lauded by Dr. Michael Pupinx at the last Commemoration Day exercises is the step taken by the Johns Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa'to prevent the curtailment of
the advance of scientific investigation in American universities.
The local chapter has taken cognizance of a tendency which,
if permitted to grow unchecked, may perceptibly impede the
progress of mature, scholarly thought. A number of Southern
universities, notably state-endowed institutions, haVe forbidden
the study of the theory of evolution, and related subjects. According to the plan of the Johns Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta
Kappa, the charters of such institutions would be revoked, and
furthermore, no charters would be granted universities that
adopted a similar policy.
It is not strange even in this enlightened day that institutions of learning should frown upon doctrines which might be
at variance with the dogmatic beliefs of some of their faculty members. But to say arbitrarily that a theory which is
the greatest influence in scientific and .philosophical circles
today may not be mentioned within their sacred portals is
equivalent to converting their colleges into theological seminaries.
Our Phi Beta Kappa chapter is to be congratulated. Once
more Johns Hopkins takes the lead in the search for truth.

Resolved, That the resigna- •
tion of R. Brent Keyser of the
office of President of the Board
of Trustees of
Johns Hopkins University, whieh office he
has held by annual election for
the period of twenty-three
years, be accepted with deep regret.
His associates having during
his absence elected him President for the twenty-fourth consecutive time, are greatly disappointed to learn that he is contemplating a trip abroad for
rest and recreation, and that he
feels that the time has come
when he should be relieved from
the responsibilities of the Presidency. Recognizing the reasonableness of his position, they
can only, though with great reluctance, accede to his wishes
and take action accordingly.
Resolved Further, That the
Board record its keen appreciation of the devoted service
which Mr. Keyser has rendered
to the University as President
of its Board of Trustees during
all of these years. This service has been invaluable, given
at great sacrifice of time, with
unflagging zeal and without
other reward than the satisfaction of doing well a task of
great importance in support of
the ideals for which the University was founded.
His Presidency has covered
about half of the life of the
University. When he was first
elected the financial situation
of the University was not encouraging.
Its assets were
less than $6,000,000.00. The gift
of Homewood had been made,
but a large part of the work of
the University was still carried
on at Howard Street in unsuitable surroundings, and funds
for the development of the new
site and new buildings thereon
were not available. One of the
greatest contributions Mr. Keyser made was the interest he
aroused in the program for the
development of the grounds and
buildings at Homewood and the
moving of the University to Its
new site. To this he gave constant attention and the admirable results obtained, and the
noble and suitable buildings
erected are due in large measure to his endeavor.
While the move to Homewood
may be regarded as the outstanding event during his administration, there have been
other notable accomplishments.
The University has been expanded by the establishment of
the School of Engineering, the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health, the Phipps Psychiatric
Clinic, and the Wilmer Ophthalmological Clinic.
These
have been made possible by
gifts aggregating more than
$20,000,000.00, and the University assets have increased to
over $30,000,000.00.
During his term of office the
number of students has increased from 700 to more than 4500.
While the functions of a Trustee are largely concerned with
the material' side of the University, Mr. Keyser's interest
in its educational progress and
policy has been most active.
During his Presidency the advances in Medical Education,
the introduction of the "full
time" system of teaching, and
the contemplate,d reorganization of the Philosophical Faculty have all required his attention, and he has had always
at heart the fullest possible development of every Department
of the University.
Resolved Further, That this
Board express its gratification
that though retiring from the
Presidency,-Mr. Keyser has consented to remain a member of
the Board, in which during his

Resolution Of Local Chapter Upholds
Complete Academic Freedom In
Present Institutions

Eight undergraduates have just
been honored by election into the
Alpha Chapter of Maryland of the
Phi Beta Kappa Society. They
are Rubin Flocks, Alger Hiss, A.
Strathman, Albert E. Blumberg.
Joel I. Seidman, Morris Rosenfeld, Louis B. Zi v, and Leon Lachman.
Graduate students in philosophy
who will soon receive their key
are Muriel, Whitbeck Brown,
Frances Adelia Hallock, Annette
Ives, ROA Clipman McDaniel,
George Sinclair Mitchell, Quentin
Iireyer Singewald, George Washington Spicer, Elmer George Suhr,
Merle Antony Tuve, and Paul
Smith Wagner.

BARNSTORMERS ELECT
RODGERS PRESIDENT
I. Evans Rodgers wag elected president of the Barnstormers Club at the annual
banquet of that organization,
held Friday. night. Walter
Broening was voted secretary. Charles Hines is business manager for next year
and Hadley King, production
manager.
About forty members,
alumni and guests attended,
including Charles Evans, star
of the Purple _Mask and
George less, who played in
the production of 1924 and
•1995.
•Pop" Swindell was presented with a silver tray,
cocktail shaker and ,eight
glasses by members of the
cast of His Majesty Bunker
Bean, in recognition of his
services as coach of this
year's production.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1926.

A NEW PRECEDENT
Has a new precedent been set as a result- of the Barnstormers' election of officers for next year? After the question
of whether a man should hold office on the campus when he
is not a regularly enrolled student in one of the undergraduate
departments has been discussed pro and con for several months,
the Barnstormers, at least, seem'to have arri-ved 'at- a definite
conclusion, as their choice for Business Manager indicates.
•
The reasons for their decision seem logical and fair. They
have picked a man who has done good work, who seems perfectly
capable of filling the position.to ,which he has been elected, and
who is practically certain of returning to the University next
year. If the matter concerned the Club alone, we,.would have
no criticism to offer.'
But the -Barnstormers are an integral part of the whole
system of- undergraduate activities which are under the control
of the Student Activities Council, and all their actions should
be viewed in the light of -this fact. No matter what the conditions may be,- the election to office of a man not in college is
in direct opposition to the system upon which Hopkins activities
are based. Each organization receives a share of the compulsory
activities fee, and it is only fair that •offices in the activities
should be open only to the reg-glarly accredited students who
help support them. Added to this .is the more important fact
that since -the activities are operated under the control of the
University; as purely secondary to regular collegiate work, they
are open only to members of -the University, with the added provision that they stand well in their studies.
The present situation seems, then, a bit,incongruous, especially in view of the fact that there were men eligible for the office
who are taking a requisite number of ourses and who have succeeded in keeping off the black list. The NEWS-LETTER would
suggest-that the matter be taken up by either the Dean or the
Student Council, so that by altering the rules to fit the case,
or by adjusting the case to fit the rules, the matter may be
settled once for all.

HOPKINS LEADS AGAIN
The latest exemplification of the "spirit of Hopkins idealism"'so strongly lauded by Dr. Michael Pupinx at the last Commemoration Day exercises is the step taken by the Johns Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta Kappa'to prevent the curtailment of
the advance of scientific investigation in American universities.
The local chapter has taken cognizance of a tendency which,
if permitted to grow unchecked, may perceptibly impede the
progress of mature, scholarly thought. A number of Southern
universities, notably state-endowed institutions, haVe forbidden
the study of the theory of evolution, and related subjects. According to the plan of the Johns Hopkins chapter of Phi Beta
Kappa, the charters of such institutions would be revoked, and
furthermore, no charters would be granted universities that
adopted a similar policy.
It is not strange even in this enlightened day that institutions of learning should frown upon doctrines which might be
at variance with the dogmatic beliefs of some of their faculty members. But to say arbitrarily that a theory which is
the greatest influence in scientific and .philosophical circles
today may not be mentioned within their sacred portals is
equivalent to converting their colleges into theological seminaries.
Our Phi Beta Kappa chapter is to be congratulated. Once
more Johns Hopkins takes the lead in the search for truth.

Resolved, That the resigna- •
tion of R. Brent Keyser of the
office of President of the Board
of Trustees of
Johns Hopkins University, whieh office he
has held by annual election for
the period of twenty-three
years, be accepted with deep regret.
His associates having during
his absence elected him President for the twenty-fourth consecutive time, are greatly disappointed to learn that he is contemplating a trip abroad for
rest and recreation, and that he
feels that the time has come
when he should be relieved from
the responsibilities of the Presidency. Recognizing the reasonableness of his position, they
can only, though with great reluctance, accede to his wishes
and take action accordingly.
Resolved Further, That the
Board record its keen appreciation of the devoted service
which Mr. Keyser has rendered
to the University as President
of its Board of Trustees during
all of these years. This service has been invaluable, given
at great sacrifice of time, with
unflagging zeal and without
other reward than the satisfaction of doing well a task of
great importance in support of
the ideals for which the University was founded.
His Presidency has covered
about half of the life of the
University. When he was first
elected the financial situation
of the University was not encouraging.
Its assets were
less than $6,000,000.00. The gift
of Homewood had been made,
but a large part of the work of
the University was still carried
on at Howard Street in unsuitable surroundings, and funds
for the development of the new
site and new buildings thereon
were not available. One of the
greatest contributions Mr. Keyser made was the interest he
aroused in the program for the
development of the grounds and
buildings at Homewood and the
moving of the University to Its
new site. To this he gave constant attention and the admirable results obtained, and the
noble and suitable buildings
erected are due in large measure to his endeavor.
While the move to Homewood
may be regarded as the outstanding event during his administration, there have been
other notable accomplishments.
The University has been expanded by the establishment of
the School of Engineering, the
School of Hygiene and Public
Health, the Phipps Psychiatric
Clinic, and the Wilmer Ophthalmological Clinic.
These
have been made possible by
gifts aggregating more than
$20,000,000.00, and the University assets have increased to
over $30,000,000.00.
During his term of office the
number of students has increased from 700 to more than 4500.
While the functions of a Trustee are largely concerned with
the material' side of the University, Mr. Keyser's interest
in its educational progress and
policy has been most active.
During his Presidency the advances in Medical Education,
the introduction of the "full
time" system of teaching, and
the contemplate,d reorganization of the Philosophical Faculty have all required his attention, and he has had always
at heart the fullest possible development of every Department
of the University.
Resolved Further, That this
Board express its gratification
that though retiring from the
Presidency,-Mr. Keyser has consented to remain a member of
the Board, in which during his
